title: Riot Composers
body:
Hi,
I'm a music composition major dreaming to be in the gaming industry regarding this particular major, involving game score production and even film scoring. I wanted to ask any Riot employee who is in the music department side of Riot to give me some guidelines on how to get involved in such profession, what _they_ did in order to be in this industry, and any kind of advice related to this would be wonderful! I was and am always fascinated on the quality of music that gaming companies are able to produce, and since gaming and music are both my biggest passions, I would like to pursue it in the right direction.

Thank you!

replies.body:
Hello & thanks for reaching out! While there isn't a single set of "rules" one can follow to enter the game music world, there are a few things that may help with those first few steps.

1) Education. You're already on top of this one! It could be studying at a university, online, or with a mentor. The most important thing is that you're always improving and continuing to learn.

2) Community. Go to as many game developer conferences, conventions, meet ups, & other events as you possibly can. Join game audio groups and reach out to people in the industry. 

3) Persistence. It can be a difficult path at times, but having the tenacity to push through, learn from that experience, and grow as a composer is important.

4) Passion. Love what you do and pour your heart into your music to create something unique for each project. 

5) Collaborate. Be a nice person who people want to be around and feel comfortable sharing candid feedback/ideas. Let them be inspired by the passion you bring to the table and have that creative trust be so solid, that you're all excited to explore new/unexpected musical ideas.

Everyone who writes music for games has a different story and their individual paths are unique to them. I hope this reply is helpful and wish you the very best of luck on your journey!

Ahh thank you so much for your reply, this is incredibly helpful! I'm sorry I couldn't get back to you much quicker; I was also wondering if it's possible to send short excerpts and get feedback from you guys/Riot at any point in time? I know there are no openings and I don't have a chance to be accepted in the industry just yet, but I would love to begin developing a style/voice of my own before too long. Thank you guys so much again!  (And sorry for copy and pasting; I wanted to thank and ask you both the same.) :)

No worries!

Unfortunately, we don't accept unsolicited demos (there's some legal reasons for that), but make sure you listen to a LOT of REALLY strong music to try and identify what makes musical voices unique. Travel back in time, too - why are Mozart, Miles Davis, Ravel or Jimi Hendrix so recognizable? Good luck!

> [{quoted}](name=Ed the Conqueror,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=Ea3fGAO3,comment-id=0002,timestamp=2018-09-17T17:36:05.324+0000)
>
Work towards the goal of having a unique and identifiable voice as a composer. Ideally, you want people to call you for what it is that _you_ do (Cliff Martinez, Thomas Newman, John Williams, hans Zimmer, etc. when you read those names, you can hear their music right away!). 
> 
> I hope this helps! Good luck in your endeavors.
> 
> Ed the Conqueror

Don't forget Ramin Djawadi. He did great work in Game of Thrones, West World and Warcraft. I feel I can definitely pick him out of a crowd musically.

I would also suggest sending a resume/demo of sorts directly to the companies you are interested in (even if there isn't a direct job opening for that specific role). Tailor the content to that specific company. I applied to Riot a few years ago as an artist, and got direct feedback from them and learned what they were looking for so I could tailor any future pursuit to their needs (what I showed them was not what they were looking for and didn't really give them a good representation of what I could actually bring to the table as a creative, which was my fault). Knowing what role you could play and how you could use that to help them is good to be aware of also, because then you'll know how to present yourself to show that. Hope that helps! Sometimes badassery and proof you know what you're doing (and work that shows your understanding of their needs) can over ride some gaps in your education/experience history~
